title: Corridor
data:
| [Dungeon features](/wiki/Dungeon_feature "Dungeon feature")      |                                             |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------- |
| [  Air](/wiki/Air "Air")                                         | [\_ Altar](/wiki/Altar "Altar")             |
| [# Corridor]()                                                   | [# Cloud](/wiki/Cloud "Cloud")              |
| [#. Drawbridge](/wiki/Drawbridge "Drawbridge")                   | [+-\| Door](/wiki/Door "Door")              |
| [. Doorway](/wiki/Doorway "Doorway")                             | [{ Fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain")     |
| [\| Headstone](/wiki/Headstone "Headstone")                      | [.  Floor](/wiki/Floor "Floor")             |
| [>< Ladder](/wiki/Ladder "Ladder")                               | [. Ice](/wiki/Ice "Ice")                    |
| [# Iron bars](/wiki/Iron_bars "Iron bars")                       | [} Lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava")                 |
| [} Moat](/wiki/Moat "Moat")                                      | [# Sink](/wiki/Sink "Sink")                 |
| [  Solid rock](/wiki/Solid_rock "Solid rock")                    | [>< Staircase](/wiki/Staircase "Staircase") |
| [\ Throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne")                                | [^" Trap](/wiki/Trap "Trap")                |
| [# Tree](/wiki/Tree "Tree")                                      | [- \| Wall](/wiki/Wall "Wall")              |
| [\~ Vibrating square](/wiki/Vibrating_square "Vibrating square") |                                             |

**Corridors**, represented by # (or # if lit, or ▒ (unlit) and ▓ (lit) with [IBMgraphics](/wiki/IBMgraphics "IBMgraphics") ), are passageways connecting [rooms](/wiki/Room "Room") in the [Dungeons of Doom](/wiki/Dungeons_of_Doom "Dungeons of Doom") and [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown"). Not all corridors lead to rooms, and many have hidden sections (called a secret passage) which must be located by [searching](/wiki/Search "Search"). Others may have [boulders](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") blocking your path. It is never impossible to progress further in the dungeon. If you come to a dead end, search all the walls until you find a secret passage. If a boulder is blocking your path, either destroy it (if you can) or drop everything you have so you can squeeze by the boulder and try to push it to a better location.

Corridors are usually single file and always unlit. [Telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy"), [Warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning") or [Infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") are helpful when walking in corridors.

[Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") and [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban "Sokoban") also have passageways and single file routes. However these are the level itself, rather than connecting rooms.

With the exception of death drops and the occasional [scroll of teleportation](/wiki/Scroll_of_teleportation "Scroll of teleportation"), there is no loot in corridors, but mercifully the only traps are from **ad aerarium **or '**Vlad was here' **[closets](/wiki/Closet "Closet").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Strategy](#Strategy)

  - [1.1 Advantages](#Advantages)
  - [1.2 Disadvantages](#Disadvantages)
  - [1.3 Tips](#Tips)

- [2 Creation of Corridors](#Creation_of_Corridors)

## Strategy

### Advantages

Corridors are usually single file, so you are less likely to be overwhelmed by numbers alone. Also, since they are only one tile wide, enemies are lined up for convenient disposal by [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand"), [spells](/wiki/Spell "Spell") or [ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack").

If you are overwhelmed by a long column of enemies you can displace your [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") and switch places with it for a few turns so you can recuperate.

### Disadvantages

The darkness means you have difficulty locating enemies without [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy"), [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning") or [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). This is a bigger problem for those roles relying on ranged attacks. A light source can helps you avoid [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster"), but it also helps enemies find you. Monsters can also block off your path, including slow-moving monsters such as [gas spores](/wiki/Gas_spore "Gas spore") and [floating eyes](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye").

### Tips

Move diagonally past corners to save time and get around faster. Corridors end when you find a [door](/wiki/Door "Door"). If you are on an early level be sure a [locked](/wiki/Locked "Locked") door isn't a [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop") door (there will be an engraving, "Closed for inventory"), before you [kick](/wiki/Kick "Kick") it down. If the corridor ends and there is no door, there is likely a secret door nearby.

Use a light source if you can spare it to avoid any awkward encounters. A [light spell](/wiki/Spellbook_of_light "Spellbook of light") is particularly useful since it is permanent.

See if you can establish a circuit, a series of rooms and corridors you can circle around indefinitely to hold off and kill monsters which are as slow or slower but more powerful than you (by running in a circle you will regain [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") and [Power](/wiki/Power "Power") over time). See [hit and run](/wiki/Hit_and_run "Hit and run").

## Creation of Corridors

You can create corridors yourself with the aid of a [pick-axe](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe"), [dwarvish mattock](/wiki/Dwarvish_mattock "Dwarvish mattock"), [dig spell](/wiki/Spellbook_of_dig "Spellbook of dig"), [wand of digging](/wiki/Wand_of_digging "Wand of digging") or polymorphing into a [rock mole](/wiki/Rock_mole "Rock mole") or [umber hulk](/wiki/Umber_hulk "Umber hulk"). If you find large amounts of [rocks](/wiki/Rock "Rock"), [gems](/wiki/Gem "Gem") or [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold") in a corridor this is a sign it has been dug by a monster. Always think of the possibility of a [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") file character.

In particular, without a means of teleportation you need this ability to reach a [Vault](/wiki/Vault "Vault"), a 2x2 room filled with gold.

[![This article may require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/b/b0/Nh343-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-343}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.

Corridor

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Dungeon features
  Air _ Altar
# Corridor # Cloud
#. Drawbridge +-| Door
. Doorway { Fountain
| Headstone .  Floor
>< Ladder . Ice
# Iron bars } Lava
} Moat # Sink
  Solid rock >< Staircase
\ Throne ^" Trap
# Tree - | Wall
~ Vibrating square

Corridors, represented by # (or # if lit, or ▒ (unlit) and ▓ (lit) with IBMgraphics ), are passageways connecting rooms in the Dungeons of Doom and Minetown. Not all corridors lead to rooms, and many have hidden sections (called a secret passage) which must be located by searching. Others may have boulders blocking your path. It is never impossible to progress further in the dungeon. If you come to a dead end, search all the walls until you find a secret passage. If a boulder is blocking your path, either destroy it (if you can) or drop everything you have so you can squeeze by the boulder and try to push it to a better location.

Corridors are usually single file and always unlit. Telepathy, Warning or Infravision are helpful when walking in corridors.

Gehennom and Sokoban also have passageways and single file routes. However these are the level itself, rather than connecting rooms.

With the exception of death drops and the occasional scroll of teleportation, there is no loot in corridors, but mercifully the only traps are from ad aerarium or 'Vlad was here' closets.

Contents

  • 1 Strategy
    • 1.1 Advantages
    • 1.2 Disadvantages
    • 1.3 Tips
  • 2 Creation of Corridors

Strategy

Advantages

Corridors are usually single file, so you are less likely to be overwhelmed by numbers alone. Also, since they are only one tile wide, enemies are lined up for convenient disposal by wands, spells or ranged attacks.

If you are overwhelmed by a long column of enemies you can displace your pet and switch places with it for a few turns so you can recuperate.

Disadvantages

The darkness means you have difficulty locating enemies without telepathy, warning or infravision. This is a bigger problem for those roles relying on ranged attacks. A light source can helps you avoid monsters, but it also helps enemies find you. Monsters can also block off your path, including slow-moving monsters such as gas spores and floating eyes.

Tips

Move diagonally past corners to save time and get around faster. Corridors end when you find a door. If you are on an early level be sure a locked door isn't a shop door (there will be an engraving, "Closed for inventory"), before you kick it down. If the corridor ends and there is no door, there is likely a secret door nearby.

Use a light source if you can spare it to avoid any awkward encounters. A light spell is particularly useful since it is permanent.

See if you can establish a circuit, a series of rooms and corridors you can circle around indefinitely to hold off and kill monsters which are as slow or slower but more powerful than you (by running in a circle you will regain HP and Power over time). See hit and run.

Creation of Corridors

You can create corridors yourself with the aid of a pick-axe, dwarvish mattock, dig spell, wand of digging or polymorphing into a rock mole or umber hulk. If you find large amounts of rocks, gems or gold in a corridor this is a sign it has been dug by a monster. Always think of the possibility of a bones file character.

In particular, without a means of teleportation you need this ability to reach a Vault, a 2x2 room filled with gold.

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.4.3. Information on this page may be out of date.

{{features}}
'''Corridors''', represented by {{lightgray|#}} (or {{white|#}} if lit, or {{lightgray|▒}} (unlit) and {{lightgray|▓}} (lit) with [[IBMgraphics]] ), are passageways connecting [[room]]s in the [[Dungeons of Doom]] and [[Minetown]]. Not all corridors lead to rooms, and many have hidden sections (called a secret passage) which must be located by [[Search|searching]]. Others may have [[boulder]]s blocking your path. It is never impossible to progress further in the dungeon. If you come to a dead end, search all the walls until you find a secret passage. If a boulder is blocking your path, either destroy it (if you can) or drop everything you have so you can squeeze by the boulder and try to push it to a better location.

Corridors are usually single file and always unlit. [[Telepathy]], [[Warning]] or [[Infravision]] are helpful when walking in corridors.

[[Gehennom]] and [[Sokoban]] also have passageways and single file routes. However these are the level itself, rather than connecting rooms.

With the exception of death drops and the occasional [[scroll of teleportation]], there is no loot in corridors, but mercifully the only traps are from '''ad aerarium '''or ''''Vlad was here' '''[[closet]]s.
== Strategy ==
===Advantages===
Corridors are usually single file, so you are less likely to be overwhelmed by numbers alone. Also, since they are only one tile wide, enemies are lined up for convenient disposal by [[wand]]s, [[spell]]s or [[ranged attack]]s.

If you are overwhelmed by a long column of enemies you can displace your [[pet]] and switch places with it for a few turns so you can recuperate.

===Disadvantages===
The darkness means you have difficulty locating enemies without [[telepathy]], [[warning]] or [[infravision]]. This is a bigger problem for those roles relying on ranged attacks. A light source can helps you avoid [[monster]]s, but it also helps enemies find you. Monsters can also block off your path, including slow-moving monsters such as [[gas spore]]s and [[floating eye]]s.

===Tips===
Move diagonally past corners to save time and get around faster. Corridors end when you find a [[door]]. If you are on an early level be sure a [[locked]] door isn't a [[shop]] door (there will be an engraving, "Closed for inventory"), before you [[kick]] it down. If the corridor ends and there is no door, there is likely a secret door nearby.

Use a light source if you can spare it to avoid any awkward encounters. A [[spellbook of light|light spell]] is particularly useful since it is permanent.

See if you can establish a circuit, a series of rooms and corridors you can circle around indefinitely to hold off and kill monsters which are as slow or slower but more powerful than you (by running in a circle you will regain [[HP]] and [[Power]] over time). See [[hit and run]].

== Creation of Corridors ==
You can create corridors yourself with the aid of a [[pick-axe]], [[dwarvish mattock]], [[spellbook of dig|dig spell]], [[wand of digging]] or polymorphing into a [[rock mole]] or [[umber hulk]]. If you find large amounts of [[rock]]s, [[gem]]s or [[gold]] in a corridor this is a sign it has been dug by a monster. Always think of the possibility of a [[bones]] file character.

In particular, without a means of teleportation you need this ability to reach a [[Vault]], a 2x2 room filled with gold.
